import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
import plotly.offline as py
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")
import seaborn as sns
colors = ["#121212","#CF673A","#E4C56F","#97A37B","#BABABA","#E8DCCC"]

import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings("ignore")

source.1a81c98e:
sns.countplot(x = dataframe['Q1'].sort_values(),
              color=colors[2],
              edgecolor='white',
              linewidth=1.5,
              saturation=1.5)

plt.ylabel('Count', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')
plt.xlabel('Age Group', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')
plt.tick_params(axis='x', which='major', labelsize=10)

plt.suptitle('Age Distribution', fontname = 'Georgia', weight='bold')
plt.show()
source.3fe23b41:
import plotly.express as px

pie_col = ["#CF673A","#E4C56F","#97A37B","#BABABA","#E8DCCC","#1274A1"]

fig = px.pie(values= dataframe['Q2'].value_counts().values, names= dataframe['Q2'].value_counts().index)

fig.update_traces(hoverinfo='label+percent',
                  textinfo='value',
                  textfont_size=20,
                  marker=dict(colors=pie_col,
                              line=dict(color='#000000', width=1)))
fig.show()
source.419e77b2:
scale =[[0, '#E4C56F'],
             [0.5,'#455C4F'],
             [1.0, '#CF673A']]


settings = [ dict(
        type = 'choropleth',
        autocolorscale = False,
        colorscale = scale,
        showscale = True,
        locations = dataframe.Q3.value_counts().index,
        z = dataframe.Q3.value_counts().values,
        locationmode = 'country names',
        text = dataframe.Q3.value_counts().index,
        marker = dict(
            line = dict(color = '#E4C56F', width = 0.5)),
            colorbar = dict(autotick = True, tickprefix = '', 
            title = 'Participants')
            )
       ]

layout = dict(
    title = 'Number of People Participated in Survey',
    geo = dict(
        showframe = True,
        showocean = True,
        oceancolor = '#1274A1',
        projection = dict(
        type = 'orthographic',
            rotation = dict(
                    lon = 60,
                    lat = 10),
        ),
        lonaxis =  dict(
                showgrid = False,
                gridcolor = '#6e6d6d'
            ),
        lataxis = dict(
                showgrid = False,
                gridcolor = '#6e6d6d'
                )
            ),
        )
fig = dict(data=settings, layout=layout)
py.iplot(fig, validate=False, filename='worldmap')
source.aafe4aba:
from textwrap import wrap

A = sns.countplot(x= dataframe['Q4'],
              color=colors[2],
              edgecolor='white',
              linewidth=1.5,
              saturation=1.5)

labels = [ '\n'.join(wrap(l, 12)) for l in dataframe['Q4'].unique()]

plt.ylabel('Count', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')
plt.xlabel('Education', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')

plt.suptitle('Formal Education', fontname = 'Georgia', weight='bold')

plt.tick_params(axis='x', which='major', labelsize=10)

A.set_xticklabels(labels, fontsize=10)

plt.show()
source.7a2da36d:
import plotly.graph_objs as go

edu = dataframe['Q5'].value_counts()

trace = go.Scatter(
    x=edu.index,
    y=edu.values,
    mode='markers',
    marker=dict(
        sizemode = 'diameter',
        sizeref = 30,
        size = edu.values,
        color = edu.values,
        colorscale='Fall',
        showscale=True
    ),
)

layout = go.Layout(
    title='Current Role'
)

data = [trace]
fig = go.Figure(data=data, layout=layout)
py.iplot(fig, filename="Current Role")
source.ccf91e98:
import plotly.graph_objs as go

edu = dataframe['Q6'].value_counts()

trace = go.Scatter(
    x=edu.index,
    y=edu.values,
    mode='markers',
    marker=dict(
        sizemode = 'diameter',
        sizeref = 30,
        size = edu.values,
        #color = np.random.randn(500), #set color equal to a variable
        color = edu.values,
        colorscale='Fall',
        showscale=True
    ),
)

layout = go.Layout(
    title='Coding Experience'
)

data = [trace]
fig = go.Figure(data=data, layout=layout)
py.iplot(fig, filename="LearningDataScience")
source.c184e3f1:
q7 = dataframe[['Q7_Part_1', 'Q7_Part_2', 'Q7_Part_3', 'Q7_Part_4', 'Q7_Part_5', 'Q7_Part_6', 'Q7_Part_7', 'Q7_Part_8', 'Q7_Part_9', 'Q7_Part_10','Q7_Part_11','Q7_Part_12', 'Q7_OTHER']]

q7.columns = ['Python', 'R', 'SQL', 'C', 'C++', 'Java', 'Javascript', 'Julia', 'Swift', 'Bash', 'MATLAB', 'None', 'Other']

q7.count().sort_values(ascending=True).plot(kind='barh',color=colors[2])


plt.xlabel('Count', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')
plt.ylabel('Languages', weight='semibold', fontname = 'Georgia')
plt.suptitle('Programming on Regular Basis', fontname = 'Georgia', weight='bold')


plt.show()

source.5518d3ba:
Data Definition
Number Question
Q1 What is your age (# years)?
Q2 What is your gender?
Q3 In which country do you currently reside?
Q4 What is the highest level of formal education that you have attained or plan to attain within the next 2 years?
Q5 Select the title most similar to your current role (or most recent title if retired)
Q6 For how many years have you been writing code and/or programming?
Q7 What programming languages do you use on a regular basis?
Q8 What programming language would you recommend an aspiring data scientist to learn first?
Q9 Which of the following integrated development environments (IDE's) do you use on a regular basis?
Q10 Which of the following hosted notebook products do you use on a regular basis?
Q11 What type of computing platform do you use most often for your data science projects?
Q12 Which types of specialized hardware do you use on a regular basis?
Q13 Approximately how many times have you used a TPU
Q14 What data visualization libraries or tools do you use on a regular basis?
Q15 For how many years have you used machine learning methods?
Q16 Which of the following machine learning frameworks do you use on a regular basis?
Q17 Which of the following ML algorithms do you use on a regular basis?
Q18 Which categories of computer vision methods do you use on a regular basis?
Q19 Which of the following natural language processing (NLP) methods do you use on a regular basis?
Q20 In what industry is your current employer/contract (or your most recent employer if retired)?
Q21 What is the size of the company where you are employed?
Q22 Approximately how many individuals are responsible for data science workloads at your place of business?
Q23 Does your current employer incorporate machine learning methods into their business?
Q24 Select any activities that make up an important part of your role at work.
Q25 What is your current yearly compensation?
Q26 Approximately how much money have you (or your team) spent on machine learning and/or cloud computing services at home (or at work) in the past 5 years?
Q27 Which of the following cloud computing platforms do you use on a regular basis?
Q28 Of the cloud platforms that you are familiar with, which has the best developer experience (most enjoyable to use)?
Q29 Do you use any of the following cloud computing products on a regular basis?
Q30 Do you use any of the following data storage products on a regular basis?
Q31 In the next 2 years, do you hope to become more familiar with any of these managed machine learning products?
Q32 Which of the following big data products (relational databases, data warehouses, data lakes, or similar) do you hope to become more familiar with in the next 2 years?
Q34 Which of the following business intelligence tools do you hope to become more familiar with in the next 2 years?
Q36 Which categories of automated machine learning tools (or partial AutoML tools) do you hope to become more familiar with in the next 2 years?
Q37 Which specific automated machine learning tools (or partial AutoML tools) do you hope to become more familiar with in the next 2 years?
Q38 In the next 2 years, do you hope to become more familiar with any of these tools for managing ML experiments?

source.a0d96424:
<div style="display:fill;
            border-radius: False;
            border-style: solid;
            border-color:#800000;
            border-style: false;
            border-width: 3px;
            color: white;
            font-size:15px;
            font-family: Sans-Serif;
            background-color:#800000;
            text-align:center;
            letter-spacing:0.5px;
            padding: 0.7em;
            text-align:left">
    
**To Begin with..**

I would like to tell a story about the data science community represented in this survey, through a combination of both narrative text and data exploration. I plan to deeply explore the data, its priorities, or discrepancies in a specific group of data science and machine learning practitioners.
    
*This is a wonderful opportunity to tell a story of the community that you feel included in and are passionate about!*

source.8c72120b: Introduction: I look up to many people here and learned a lot in the past few months and want to get involved in the most creative competition of Kaggle's 5th Survey. Starting from my first few lines of code in data science to pursuing Masters in Data Science, Kaggle and the wonderful community has been my backbone. So, thank you. Now, lets dive into the world of Analysis and Story Telling!
